Description: Fragment of Egyptian terracotta figure in the form of a tragic mask. Traces of white coating, single piercing at back. Fragment from the tragic mask of a youth with falling locks, left side of locks preserved only. A hole suggests this was originally suspended from a wall or similar. Hollow; probably from a one-piece mould. The front is covered with traces of white coating and possibly black paint. Red-brown Nile silt with grey core.
Curator's comments: Parallels from similar masks from Egypt (Bailey 2008, no.3564, GR1926,0412.2), including Naukratis (ibid. no.3567; GR1886,0401.1439). Other examples of tragic masks from Naukratis, but without the locks preserved are also known (Cambridge, Fitzwilliam Museum GR.301.1899; Oxford, Ashmolean Museum AN1886.478; Cambridge, Museum of Classical Archaeology NA718; Greenock, McLean Museum & Art Gallery 1987.284). Likely of 3rd to 2nd century BC Ptolemaic date based on form and context.
Bibliographic references: Leonard 2001 / Ancient Naukratis: Excavations at a Greek Emporion in Egypt, Part II: The excavations at Kom Hadid. (p. 165, no.2, pl. 3.2.)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.312) (Phase 3)
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: pl. 3.2, p. 165. no.2 (catalogue number)
